Easy Pork Stew

Jump to Recipe

If you're searching for a hearty and comforting dish that warms the soul, look no further than this easy pork stew recipe. Made with tender pork shoulder, fresh vegetables, and aromatic herbs, this stew is not only delicious but also simple to prepare. Ideal for family dinners or chilly evenings, this dish brings together the rich flavors of pork and the earthiness of root vegetables, creating a meal that is both satisfying and nutritious. In this recipe, we’ll guide you through the steps to create a savory pork stew that is sure to become a staple in your kitchen. With just a few ingredients and a pot, you can whip up a delightful dish that fills your home with inviting aromas. Let’s dive into the details and discover how to make this scrumptious pork stew!

Ingredients

pork shoulder, cubed

Pork shoulder is a great choice for stews due to its marbling and fat content, which helps keep the meat tender and juicy. If you can't find pork shoulder, you can substitute it with pork butt or even beef chuck for a different flavor profile. Make sure to brown the meat well to develop a rich flavor.

carrots, sliced

Carrots add sweetness and texture to the stew. For a different flavor, you can substitute with parsnips or sweet potatoes. Remember to slice them evenly to ensure they cook at the same rate. Adding them later in the cooking process will keep them firmer.

potatoes, diced

Potatoes provide heartiness to the stew. Use waxy varieties like Yukon Gold for a creamy texture or starchy ones like Russets for a fluffier texture. If you want to cut down on carbs, consider substituting with cauliflower or turnips.

onion, chopped

Onions add a foundational flavor to the stew. You can substitute with shallots for a milder taste or leeks for a sweeter flavor. Sautéing them until translucent enhances their sweetness, which balances the dish.

garlic, minced

Garlic adds depth of flavor. Use fresh garlic for the best taste, but if you’re in a pinch, you can substitute with garlic powder (1/8 teaspoon per clove). For a milder flavor, you can roast the garlic before adding it to the stew.

beef broth

Beef broth adds richness to the stew. You can substitute it with chicken broth or vegetable broth if you prefer a lighter flavor. If using a low-sodium broth, adjust the salt accordingly. For deeper flavor, consider adding a splash of red wine or soy sauce.

bay leaves

Bay leaves impart a subtle aromatic flavor. Make sure to remove them before serving, as they can be tough to chew. If you don’t have bay leaves, you can substitute with a pinch of thyme or oregano, but use them sparingly.

thyme (dried)

Dried thyme is great for stews as it infuses the dish with earthy notes. If you have fresh thyme, use about three times the amount (3 teaspoons). For a different flavor, you can also use rosemary or Italian seasoning.

salt

Salt enhances the flavors of the stew. Start with a small amount and adjust to taste as it cooks. If using salted broth, be cautious with additional salt. Consider using kosher salt for better control over seasoning.

pepper

Freshly ground black pepper adds a nice kick to the stew. You can substitute with white pepper for a milder flavor. If you like heat, consider adding crushed red pepper flakes or a dash of hot sauce.

olive oil

Olive oil is great for sautéing and adds a fruity flavor. If you prefer a higher smoke point, you can use canola or vegetable oil. For added flavor, try infusing your oil with garlic or herbs before cooking.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Heat Olive Oil

    In a large pot, heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil over medium heat. This oil will help in browning the pork and adding flavor to your stew.

  • Step 2: Brown the Pork Shoulder

    Add 2 pounds of cubed pork shoulder to the hot oil. Brown the meat on all sides for about 5-7 minutes. This step is crucial as browning adds depth of flavor to the stew.

  • Step 3: Sauté Onion and Garlic

    Remove the browned pork from the pot and set aside. In the same pot, add 1 chopped onion and 4 minced garlic cloves. Sauté until the onion is softened and translucent, about 3-4 minutes.

  • Step 4: Combine Ingredients

    Return the browned pork to the pot. Add 3 sliced carrots, 3 diced potatoes, 4 cups of beef broth, 2 bay leaves, 1 teaspoon of dried thyme, and salt and pepper to taste. Stir well to combine all ingredients.

  • Step 5: Bring to a Boil

    Increase the heat and bring the mixture to a boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low and cover the pot. This helps the flavors meld together and the pork to tenderize.

  • Step 6: Simmer the Stew

    Let the stew simmer for about 1.5 hours. Check occasionally to ensure it isn’t boiling too vigorously. The pork should be tender and the vegetables cooked through.

  • Step 7: Final Touches

    Before serving, remove the bay leaves from the stew. Taste and adjust seasoning with additional salt and pepper if necessary.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I properly cube pork shoulder?

To cube pork shoulder, first, make sure your knife is sharp. Place the pork on a cutting board and trim away any excess fat. Cut the pork into strips about 1-2 inches wide, then turn the strips and cut them into cubes. Don't worry about making them perfectly uniform; just aim for similar sizes for even cooking.

What’s the best way to sauté onions and garlic?

To sauté onions and garlic, heat your olive oil in the pot on medium heat. Add the chopped onions first and cook for 3-5 minutes until they start to soften and become translucent. Then, add the minced garlic and sauté for another 1-2 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent burning. Garlic cooks faster than onions, so it's important to add it later.

How can I tell when the pork is browned properly?

The pork is properly browned when it develops a golden-brown crust on all sides. This usually takes about 5-7 minutes. You can check by lifting a piece with tongs and looking for a nice dark color. Don't overcrowd the pot; if necessary, brown the pork in batches to ensure each piece gets seared.

Is it necessary to remove the bay leaves before serving?

Yes, it's important to remove bay leaves before serving as they are not edible and can be tough to chew. Make it a habit to check for them before plating your stew.

How do I adjust the seasoning to my taste?

Start by adding a little salt and pepper during cooking, then taste the stew before serving. You can add more salt, pepper, or thyme as needed. Remember, you can always add more, but you can’t take it away, so add gradually!

What should I do if my stew is too thick?

If your stew is too thick, simply add a little more beef broth or water to reach your desired consistency. Stir well and let it simmer for a few more minutes to heat through.

How can I ensure the pork is tender?

Low and slow is the key! Simmering your pork stew on low heat for about 1.5 hours allows the connective tissues in the pork to break down, resulting in tender meat. Avoid high heat, which can make the pork tough.

What is the best way to store leftover pork stew?

Allow the stew to cool to room temperature, then transfer it to an airtight container and refrigerate. It can last in the fridge for 3-4 days or can be frozen for up to 3 months. Just reheat thoroughly before serving.

Can I add other vegetables to the stew?

Absolutely! Feel free to add other vegetables like peas, green beans, or bell peppers. Just remember to adjust the cooking time as needed, depending on how quickly they cook.

What should I serve with pork stew?

Pork stew pairs wonderfully with crusty bread, rice, or a simple green salad. These sides can help balance the rich flavors of the stew.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

The stew is naturally gluten-free but can be made even more suitable for gluten-sensitive individuals by ensuring the beef broth is gluten-free. For a low-carb option, substitute the potatoes with turnips or cauliflower. If you want a dairy-free version, simply omit any cream or cheese toppings. For a lighter version, you can use lean pork cuts or reduce the amount of pork and increase the vegetables.

Pairings

This Pork Stew pairs beautifully with crusty bread, which can be used to soak up the rich broth. For a heartier meal, consider serving with a side of creamy mashed potatoes or garlic bread. Complementary beverages include a robust red wine such as a Cabernet Sauvignon or a smooth, rich beer like a stout. For a non-alcoholic option, a tart apple cider can enhance the flavors of the stew.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the stew in deep bowls, garnished with fresh parsley or thyme for a pop of color and freshness. Accompany with a side of pickled vegetables to add a tangy contrast to the richness of the stew. For an upscale touch, consider serving with a dollop of sour cream or a sprinkle of freshly grated parmesan cheese on top. Ensure the stew is served hot, ideally at a temperature of around 160°F (71°C) to maintain its warmth and flavor.

Easy Pork Stew

135 min
$25
450 kcal

Servings: 6

Dietary Tags:

Cuisine:

Description

A hearty and comforting stew with tender pork and flavorful vegetables, perfect for a cozy dinner.

Ingredients

  • pork shoulder, cubed: 2 pounds
  • carrots, sliced: 3
  • potatoes, diced: 3
  • onion, chopped: 1
  • garlic, minced: 4 cloves
  • beef broth: 4 cups
  • bay leaves: 2
  • thyme (dried): 1 teaspoon
  • salt: to taste
  • pepper: to taste
  • olive oil: 2 tablespoons
